content:
I enjoyed this puzzle.

A scenario which none of the test cases cover is a potential father who shares only the same chromosome as the mother does with the child, e.g.:

Mother Alice: Ab
Child Bob: Az
Father Charlie: Ac

Charlie could have produced Bob with some other mother, but not with Alice because the 'z' doesn't come from either parent.

My initial code checked only that the child matched some chromosome from each parent, and so passed all tests even though it would have failed this situation.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The description is clear, the tests have good coverage, the initial bugs were quickly dealth with, and the difficulty level is appropiate.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice original puzzle! Good job.
Nice idea ! I find it very fun to solve. Hope it'll get public

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun, original, well made, good tests üëç

I think it would be better for accessibility reasons to not split the sections like that, I don't think a screen reader would properly read "~ ~ ~ E x a m p l e ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~".

I'm passing everything but the last validator. My issue is how my code deals with this chromosome pair (at index 8):

- Mother:  51
- Child:      15
(Expected output chromosome pair)
- Orlando: 52

It's not hard to fix it, but it probably requires a test for awareness, otherwise we get the why did I fail last validator etc.

For reference, my logic is something like (ruby):

[...]
    if chrom_child.include? chrom_mother[0]
      chrom_child[chrom_child.index(chrom_mother[0]) ^ 1]
    else
      chrom_child[chrom_child.index(chrom_mother[1]) ^ 1]
    end
[...]

This gives 1 as a missing chromosome for that position, but Orlando's chromosome pair at that position is 52 so I don't find a father.

Test 2:
[...]
Chris                10 cP )7 l8 bK )2 -;
[...]

-> "Next numOfPossibleFathers Lines: Possible father's name: some spaces, followed by some number of pairOfChroms (each separated by a space)"

There is no ":" after Chris.

Goal section
* Please add full-stops where appropriate.

* Please change "contribute" to "contributes".

* Maury Povich pops up at the end of the text suddenly without any mention earlier üòÆ Would it be better to move the inspiration note to the beginning and mention the name of the show and/or the host? (I don't know "Maury Povich" without searching.)

Output section
* Please remove the quotation mark.

Cases
* I haven't looked at the cases in detail, but I would suggest to slightly bump up and standardise the difficulty of the latter cases as follows (you may have implemented some of it but it doesn't look consistent - e.g. Test 5 is easier than Validator 5 and they look dissimilar to me in terms of test coverage):

   ‚Ä¢ Test/Validator 3: Only two possible options remain after checking the 1st pair of chromosomes, and one gets the answer after checking 1 more pair.

   ‚Ä¢ Test/Validator 4: Only two possible options remain after checking the 1st pair of chromosomes, and one gets the answer after checking many more pairs.

   ‚Ä¢ Test/Validator 5: More than two possible options remain after checking the 1st pair of chromosomes, and one may eliminate an option after checking some more pairs, eliminate another after checking more, etc.

   ‚Ä¢ Test/Validator 6: ALL options remain after checking the 1st pair of chromosomes, and one may eliminate an option after checking some more pairs, eliminate another after checking more, etc. One does not get the final answer until one checks the LAST pair of chromosomes.

Thanks.

Thanks a ton, as always‚Ä¶. 

I‚Äôm slowly working through these.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~

RE Please change "contribute" to "contributes".

That just sounds so funny to me. So I did a deep dive and found this webpage. Please see example #2 where it treats ‚Äúeach‚Äù as plural.
https://www.masterclass.com/articles/is-each-singular-or-plural

So maybe it‚Äôs fine, as is ???
Thanks.  Fixed

Hi Rafa -- Good catch and comment... 

I think I'm going to redo Test/Validator #8 entirely.
And I'll let you know when it's done... probably tomorrow.
Thanks‚Ä¶ I minimized those headings ‚Ä¶ is it OK now?
Thanks
Thanks (me too)
Thank you !!!
Thanks Rafa !
Yes, thanks

I have changed entirely Test/Validator 8 and I believe I have put a ton of examples of the issue you describe in both.  

Have a look and let me know, please.

My previous code doesn't pass test 8 now, so that's a win.

Then I fixed the logic and managed to pass everything. Looks good to me.

My bad, please ignore that point.

I'll look at the cases again after you're done updating üôÇ

Changing those test/validators as you suggested is a great idea. 

I want to figure out how to generate those test cases programmatically and that‚Äôs gonna take me a few days. 

But I think the rest of your suggestions are now implemented and I have reworded  things a lot. 

Please have a review of that part now if you like

I figured out how to program that ... so the test/validators are ready for you to look at now too :)

And I added another test/validator (#7) where all men could be the father except for a single "bad" chromPair (located randomly somewhere in each)

Looks good to me!

I even find it fun to solve each case by just processing it in my brain instead of with a code üòÇ And while doing so, I discovered an interesting pair of chromosomes in Test 6:

Mother: QX
Child: XQ

In most cases, I'd just check, in each pair, which chromosome is shared by both Mother and Child, and the unmatched one in Child must be the one contributed by Father. But in the pair I quoted, that strategy doesn't work! It'll be interesting to have a pair of cases where there are many such pairs ü§™

I like that... I made test/validator #8 for that now.

I kinda cheated by reducing the number of characters possible to force that.
Hopefully that won't freak players out.

I'm always open to any more feedback... let me know :)

Thank you. I would suggest to modify Test/Validator 8 further by throwing in a few more pairs of chromosomes where Mother = Child using just one single character, e.g. Mother is 11 and Child is 11, and for some of such pairs all possible Fathers contain 1, while for other pairs one or more do not contain 1.

By the way, I tried Validator 8 by reading the chromosomes starting from the right instead of the left, and it just took me 2 "moves" to narrow down to Orlando üòÇ

Well of course, anyone who knows Orlando, knows he's the father.  I mean look at the eyes and the nose.  (Just kidding.)

Thanks for the feedback.  I'll work on that, and let you know when done.

I have changed entirely Test/Validator 8 and I believe I have addressed this fully now.

Have a look and let me know, please.

I would suggest rearranging a bit so that a few more confusing pairs be placed at the right hand side of the strings (just like Test/Validator 7) so that players who check from the end will still have to deal with a considerable number of such pairs.

Thanks 5DN1L -- I love how you often push me to do better :)
It really helps me learn 

I added another Test/Validator now where each dude is a 95% match, and the 5% is scattered thru out.

Brilliant!

I thank you for bearing with me too üòõ
